awd_titl_txt: Probing Fundamental Physics with Gravitational Experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
In modern physics Nature is described by two theories. One is the “Standard Model,” which describes all material properties with quantum particles; the other is “General Relativity”, Einstein’s theory that describes gravitation.  Most physicists think that there must be a connection between these two theories, but to date there is no experimental signature for such a connection.  Furthermore, the discoveries of dark matter and dark energy suggest that gravitational phenomena exist that lie outside of General Relativity. The group at the University of Washington specializes in measuring ultra-feeble forces to search for unprecedentedly small deviations from gravity as described by General Relativity. While observing any deviations from General Relativity would be a revolutionary scientific discovery, it may also have consequences for future technical applications of GPS or next-generation precision clocks. Technology and technical expertise developed by this group has applications ranging from industrial metrology to earthquake prediction. Modern ideas for unifying gravity and particle physics, as well as the observation of dark energy and dark matter, suggest that some aspects of gravity remain undiscovered. The table-top experiments of the University of Washington gravity laboratory (Eöt-Wash Group) provide a unique opportunity to search for new physics at the intersection of General Relativity, cosmology, and particle physics. The group is a leader in the ﬁeld of ultra-weak force detection through technical expertise, innovation, and by responding to the most relevant timely and timeless physics questions. 

Speciﬁcally, the group will:1) Test the equivalence principle (EP): It is almost certain that any connection between General Relativity and the Standard Model violates the EP. The group’s torsion balances provide the most precise EP-tests at distances below 100 km. With highly-increased sensitivity through fused silica torsion ﬁbers, a new EP measurement will be carried out. The experiment’s generality and relevance to cosmology will be enhanced by probing the EP with hydrogen test masses. 2) Test Newton’s Inverse-Square Law at short distances: The Eöt-Wash group has measured and tested gravity at distances of 41 μm. The group will use its expertise to design and build a new instrument aimed at measuring and testing gravity down to distances of 25 μm. 3) Advance the frontier of low-frequency ultra-small-force technology: Innovative and challenging technology development has enabled the group’s success. With a vision towards the future of gravitational research (including LIGO), the group will continue pursuing development of cryogenic instruments and interferometric torsion balance readout.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The contemporary picture of fundamental physics consists two well-tested theories: General Relativity, which describes gravity, and the Standard Model which describes electro-magnetism, the weak and the strong interactions. Very surprisingly though, there is no experimental evidence for a connection between these two highly successful theories. Furthermore, the discoveries of the unexplained cosmological phenomena of dark matter and dark energy, hint that there is a lot more fundamental physics that needs to be discovered in which gravity is also involved.

Our lab is focusing on making the most precise experimental tests of gravity. Any ever-so-small break-down of gravity’s underlying concepts would provide the basis to formulate better more all-encompassing theories. In particular, we are testing the equivalence principle, which states that all types of masses (and energy) are attracted by gravity in precisely the same way. To do this we have developed state-of-the-art highly sophisticated torsion balances. By installing the torsion balances on a continuously rotating platform we were able search for incredibly small differential accelerations between two materials.  By monitoring these differential acceleration towards a variety of gravitational source masses we are able to test the equivalence principle with unprecedented precision and the biggest generality possible. For example, our torsion balance can test whether galactic dark matter causes any non-gravitational long-range forces onto normal matter.

With a cryogenic torsion balance instrument, we have made the most sensitive test whether gravity treats superconducting Cooper pairs differently than ordinary non-superconducting matter.

We have tested concepts for a new method of testing the 1/r^2 law of gravity at very small distances (< 40 micrometers). If gravity breaks down at very small distances, this could help elucidate phenomena associated with the cosmological dark energy or it may provide evidence for the extra dimensions of string theory.

All our measurements are enabled by development of one-of-a-kind instruments, technology and methodology. Some of the technology and know-how is finding applications in other instruments such as the gravitational wave detectors or in the burgeoning field of rotational seismology.

We have published our scientific results in broadly available journals and presented our work at meetings world-wide.

Very importantly, through our research we have trained educators, scientists and engineers to pursue STEM knowledge and to support the fast growing demand for creative high-tech experts and leaders in industry.

Through active outreach to grade schools, high schools, colleges, other universities, as well as the public in general, we hope to have instilled and satisfied curiosity in the secrets of the universe.

During the period of this grant funding, our research was awarded the Breakthrough Prize in Fundamental Physics to Adelberger, Gundlach and Heckel.
